ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was a combination of synchronous meetings and asynchronous recorded lectures.
Live virtual problem solving sessions.
This class was a combination of recorded lectures, live virtual lectures, and virtual small group work
Online synchronous classes with in-class group exercises, and pre-recorded lectures from Canvas.
recorded lectures, virtual group work
This class consisted of recorded lectures (usually 1 hour a week, split between a linguistics topic and a statistics topic) as well as live virtual lectures.
office hours
live virtual lecture
Live virtual lecture
There were prerecorded lectures as well.
combination of mandatory live virtual lectures and separate recorded lectures
Online recorded lectures to watch before the live virtual lecture/class, quizzes, p-sets
There were pre-recorded lectures every week as well as live virtual sessions every week.
N/A
Live virtual class that was either lecture or group work; two prerecorded lectures every week

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learnt the basics of R, as well as some useful concepts in statistics and linguistics.
How to use R to conduct basic data analysis on linguistic datasets.
I learned the basics of R and how to approach linguistic data with it.

Many of the initial R and statistical concepts in the first half to the term will be straightforward and familiar to Statistics or CS majors. The linguistics topics can get a bit dry, but you learn about phonology, phonetics, etc. You wont be an expert in any of the linguistics concepts  theyre more used as context for practicing with R and statistical analysis techniques used in academic research. You learn a bit about mixed effects models, which is something I wasnt taught in any of the Statistics & Data Science courses. I got better at visualizations with ggplot2, and learned about some common experimental/research best practices.
I learned how to analyze linguistic data sets using R.
I learned how to use R to make graphs and evaluate models, and I learned how to analyze the results of statistical tests in R.
Great understanding of statistical modeling and graphing in R in addition to an understanding of basic linguistic fields and ability to interpret a variety of types of linguistic data
working with linguistic data sets, learning foundation linguistics concepts, using R to conduct analyses
I don't think I learned that much from the course. The linguistic concepts are briefly discussed and not explained very well and the application of R is elementary and tedious.
I learned how to do statistical tests, linear regression, and logistic regression using R. Definitely also got much more familiar with ggplot as well
How to use R, how to write a quantitative research paper for Statistics

We were given a broad overview of different topics in linguistics as well as different statistical tests and models commonly used in linguistics research at the same time. For statistical concepts, we covered graphing and visualization, statistical tests, regression models, and mixed effects models among others. And this was all in R.
Basic linguistic theory, how to do data analysis in R (visualization, statistical testing, and model fitting).
Basic linguistics topics, basic statistical methods and tests in R, how linguistics topics can be evaluated/explored statistically
Knowledge of statistical methods and how to apply them to linguistic studies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: office hours were really helpful, analyzed some interesting data sets. Grades were released very consistently/class felt very organized overall. Found class exercises to be helpful with psets. Professor gave good, personal feedback on homework, which I appreciated.

Weaknesses: live lectures didn't have slides, so sometimes it felt like I was just being talked at (professor would lecture with no slides) -- thus really easy to zone out. I wish the solutions to the class exercises would be released, so we could use those to help with the psets (just the grade sometimes didn't help). I also found the take-home midterm to be way too long (and the questions themselves repetitive) given the amount of time we were allotted. Additionally, the majority of the midterm was on content we hadn't finished a class exercise or pset on yet, so we had no idea (i.e. no grade) if what we were doing was right, since we didn't practice it beforehand. I also felt like some of the psets were unnecessarily long/tedious.

Overall, found this class interesting, but it felt more like an R class for linguistics students rather than a linguistics elective for people who already knew some R and were hoping to learn more about linguistic concepts.

Strengths: Professor Sanker is easy to reach over email and in office hours, coursework was graded very quickly and fairly, feedback was thorough and helpful
Weaknesses: The live virtual lectures were quite dry, I wish the course had spent more time on explaining exactly how R works instead of providing commands to copy and paste into the program.

The final exam was absurdly long and repetitive. We had four datasets and, although each one had different properties and involved different linguistics topics, the analysis used was really similar and ended up being tedious and frustrating. It often felt like some of our assignments followed a similar pattern  longer than they needed to be, with ambiguous questions and the need to explain our results in terms of linguistics concepts we did not have a solid grasp on. I think a lot of students were quite stressed because we were made to do an in-class exercise during finals period, had a long assignment due that week Thursday, and then an extremely long final exam due five days later. It felt like there was too much going on during that time to focus on any one thing.

However, some of the strengths of this class were that the professor pre-recorded our lectures in a very straightforward, organized format with slides to go with them. Her slides, R commands notes, and other cheat-sheets were always useful when working on assignments or in class. It also felt like the in-class exercises, despite being extra work on top of the recorded lectures, were helpful for practicing new concepts with the help of our TF and professor. 

A really great part of this class and professor was that we received detailed, careful feedback on every one of our assignments. Given how long many of these were, it was impressive that the professor/TF was able to do this for us. Their feedback was specific and often quite helpful for later assignments. It definitely showed how much the professor cared about the material!

Interesting readings! Lecture slides would be helpful during the live lectures.  More basic introduction to R itself, and not just statistics, would have helped me-- some knowledge of programming seemed to be presumed even though the syllabus said it wasn't.
really no weaknesses. lectures could perhaps be slightly more engaging, but virtual format is likely at fault.

Great course to gain additional exposure to linguistics concepts and pacing and material covered felt very conducive to learning many important foundational concepts in S&DS in an applied setting. Sometimes felt the recorded and live lectures heavily overlapped in content and that both were not necessary.  Workload is manageable but it is easy to lose points on the psets since the things asked in the questions are not everything necessary to receive full credit.
The lectures were very dry and did not have any presentations to accompany them which made them even more difficult to follow.

I definitely learned a lot, but this was because the homeworks and take-home exams were extremely tedious and essentially asked for the same statistical questions over and over again. The midterm mostly sucked as well, because we were expected to use a form of statistical analysis that we had never gotten explicit examples of interpretation nor gotten feedback on. However, grading in the class overall was very fair. The breakout rooms every week were also lowkey painful, although I think that's more attributed to online classes than the fault of the class.

The online lectures were great! They were clear, concise, and helpful (especially the slides). The live virtual lectures were very hard to follow; it would help to have slides that clearly delineate the concept being explained. Or, it would also be helpful to turn the lecture time into another sort of Q&A session or office hours, so people could get more help.

Strengths:
- Provides a solid introduction to data analysis
- Lots of hands-on work with analyzing real experimental data from linguistics papers
- Professor and TA were extremely helpful during class and gave great feedback on all assignments
Weaknesses:
- Course was more of a "statistics for linguistics majors" one than a "linguistics for statistics majors" one

Strengths: smooth integration of linguistics topics with statistical methods, materials kept track of well, good feedback

Weaknesses: poor/ineffective use of materials (like textbooks/papers), "throw into the deep end" feeling with R exercises and homeworks

Overall, this is a good course. Problem sets and exams are fair and the material is interesting. One improvement I'd suggest is to also make announcements on Canvas instead of just on the not recorded lecture meetings. Sometimes it's easy to miss important announcements and due dates and it would be nice to not have to bother Professor Sanker or our TF for simple questions like 'when will the take-home midterm be released?'

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Aside from the in class lectures, this course was well organized for virtual learning.

Although the pre-recorded lectures were fine for covering the basic materials, it made in-class discussions (on days without exercises) somewhat pointless. When we did meet synchronously, if we werent doing an exercise it didnt seem like our lectures followed any clear structure, and they didnt involve any visuals or slides for the most part. It was as if we were meeting just to say we had. 

But the in-class exercises, especially as they were just graded for credit not accuracy, were helpful for practicing new concepts and getting live feedback from the TF or professor. It was helpful to share our code on the Zoom screen so other people could give tips to improve it.
Group work (and especially letting us choose our groups) was helpful.
I think that the live lectures could have been shortened if we already had to watch pre-recorded lectures.
The online virtual lectures were great!
I think perhaps the course might have been better if one live class was dedicated to lecture and another class was dedicated to the group exercises because sometimes it felt like a lot of work.

Succeeded:
- Virtual classes were more or less equivalent to what would be expected in-person
Did not succeed:
- Working on in-class exercises virtually is not so easy

Succeeded: consistently-formed breakout rooms with the same students, TA/professor traveling from breakout room to breakout room to answer questions, prerecorded lectures

Could be improved: in-class lectures were poorly structured and difficult to follow -- maybe a powerpoint or visual guide would help

I wish Professor Sanker recorded our live lecture meetings. She quickly goes over very useful R commands and troubleshooting tips and I often miss out on some important information because I can't jot it down fast enough. Recorded lectures would allow me to go back and write down what she gave.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course does not assume any background in linguistics or statistics, but it is very useful to have some familiarity with programming. I would not recommend the course to a student who has no background in programming or statistics.

I would if you need an elective credit for the S&DS major, as for the most part the work was not difficult even without listening to the lectures. It was pretty clear what we needed to do and when, which is good. 

I only took issue with the last few weeks of class, the final, and the midterm, because it felt like the questions were ambiguous and it was at times unclear what the professor wanted us to do.

It's good for people that already understand statistics and programming and want to learn about linguistics, but  as someone who's already taken some linguistics, it didn't familiarize me with stats and programming as much as I hoped it would.
absolutely
Yes. Really good exposure to linguistics concepts and material is layed out very well for learning. Good place to gain more experience with R
I would not recommend it. The assignments are unnecessarily long and tedious.

I think this is a good class to gain a good foundation of regression and statistical tests, but this is probably one of the most tedious classes I've ever taken at Yale. The lengths of homeworks and take home exams could have been cut in half (lol for example my knitted file for the final exam was deadass 45 pages), and I would still have learned a lot. Otherwise, this is a solid class to take to fulfill a BA requirement for S&DS.
Yes, especially if you're doing it to help with your major or your certificate. It's a pretty chill course, and the instructors really care. The lectures can be a bit harder to follow, though!
Yes, if you're a linguistics major looking for a solid introduction to data analysis. If not, then a general S&DS course is probably a better fit.
Yes, to students interested in linguistics and statistics
